sn11.13:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn11.13:1.3: Then Mahāli the Licchavi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn11.13:2.1: “Sir, have you seen Sakka, lord of gods?”
sn11.13:4.1: “But surely, sir, you must have seen someone who looked like Sakka.
sn11.13:4.2: For Sakka is hard to see.”
sn11.13:5.1: “Mahāli, I understand Sakka. And I understand the things that he undertook and committed to, which enabled him to achieve the status of Sakka.
sn11.13:6.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he was a brahmanical student named Magha. That’s why he’s called Maghavā.
sn11.13:7.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave gifts carefully. That’s why he’s called Sakka, the careful.
sn11.13:8.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave gifts in stronghold after stronghold. That’s why he’s called Purindada, the stronghold-giver.
sn11.13:9.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave the gift of a guest house. That’s why he’s called Vāsava, the houser.
sn11.13:10.1: Sakka thinks of a thousand things in a moment. That’s why he’s called Sahassakkha, Thousand-Eye.
sn11.13:11.1: Sakka’s wife is the demon maiden named Sujā. That’s why he’s called Sujampati, Sujā’s husband.
sn11.13:12.1: Sakka rules as sovereign lord over the gods of the Thirty-Three. That’s why he’s called lord of gods.
sn11.13:13.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.
sn11.13:13.3: As long as I live, may I support my parents.
sn11.13:13.4: As long as I live, may I honor the elders in the family.
sn11.13:13.5: As long as I live, may I speak gently.
sn11.13:13.6: As long as I live, may I not speak divisively.
sn11.13:13.7: As long as I live, may I live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.
sn11.13:13.8: As long as I live, may I speak the truth.
sn11.13:13.9: As long as I live, may I be free of anger, or should anger arise, may I quickly get rid of it.
sn11.13:13.10: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.
sn11.13:14.1: A person who respects their parents,
sn11.13:14.2: and honors the elders in the family,
sn11.13:14.3: whose speech is gentle and courteous,
sn11.13:15.1: who’s committed to getting rid of stinginess,
sn11.13:15.2: is truthful, and has mastered anger:
sn11.13:15.4: call them truly a good person.”
